page.title: 01Changue Beat, Carrick Forest
page.content: This is Galloway hill country, rolling plateux with peaty grassland up to 500m. Steep but not precipitous glens and small streas converging towards the conservation village of Barr (just off NW corner of block, 100m above sea level). Most of the land was plantedwith conifer, mainly Sitka Spruce by the Forestry Commission between 1938 and 1950. Extensive windblow starting in late 70's necessitated premature clear felling of much of the forest followed by immediate replanting . Felling is continuing. There is a forest workers agricultural holding in sq2 of block. The 5 SW sqs are mainly soft wet peaty grass moorland, providing upland sheep pastures and summer grazing for beef cattle. A derelict shepherds cottage abandoned some years ago,lies sq 10.
